item.summary: Cannot compile 0.10.0 development tip with gcc-4.6.x

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
According to the Apache Thrift site:

Basic requirements

    A relatively POSIX-compliant *NIX system
        Cygwin or MinGW can be used on Windows (but there are better options, see below)
    g++ 4.2
    boost 1.53.0
    Runtime libraries for lex and yacc might be needed for the compiler.

So either https://thrift.apache.org/docs/install/ is correct and this is a bug, or https://thrift.apache.org/docs/install/ is wrong and needs to be updated. The CMake build did not complain about the compiler or boost version in use during configuration.

nsuke any suggestions here? It looks like new code for THRIFT-2835 has broken some older environments. I got VS2010 working under THRIFT-3936 but this older gcc environment doesn't seem to work any more. Either we need to change the minimum requirements that we publish on the apache web site or we need to fix the code. Let me know.
Assigned to @nsuke initially; I can help out just let me know if we need to fix the code or we're going to change the minimum required version of third party libraries for 0.10.0. cc: jfarrell

jking3 our CI uses boost 1.53 on CentOS 7
https://travis-ci.org/apache/thrift/jobs/163474948#L406
So boost version does not need an update.

On the other hand, we list GCC 4.2 as minimum requirement that sounds unlikely to work.
Our CI uses 4.8 on CentOS 7 and Ubuntu 14.04.
I'd suggest listing what we're testing as the required version.

One way to keep GCC req sufficiently low would be to build boost 1.53 on our CentOS 6 CI (GCC 4.4) and then run C/C++/native extension builds.

Also a quick work around for GCC 4.6 or lower is to set WITH_PLUGIN default value to OFF if old GCC is found when configuring.

Let me verify that if I switch to the default compiler for 14.04.2 LTS that it works (I think it is 4.8.2, or close to that). If that does work then I will add the cmake and autoconf change to disable WITH_PLUGIN if that resolves the issue. Would you consider this a blocker for the 0.10.0 release? I currently have it linked as required.

I would say that if its not working for VS2010 don't try and force it, try and keep to the latest LTS versions and possible the previous version. Same goes for centos, ubuntu and debian which we should have Dockerfiles for and should test and show usage and install examples for each client lib within.
Confirmed: 4.8.4 builds fine; 4.6.4 builds fine if you give cmake the option -DWITH_PLUGIN=OFF.

VS2013 (and earlier) fix is in THRIFT-3936 which has a PR out for review already. I think we should support VS2013 so we should get that in before cutting 0.10.0 RC.

I'm going to modify the cmake and autoconf environments to set WITH_PLUGIN=OFF if the compiler is gcc and older than 4.8. This probably doesn't have to hold up the release however so I have removed the dependency link in Jira for this one.
sounds like you have most of this worked out all ready, lets get the patches in for 0.10.0
Hopefully I got the autoconf stuff right. Submitting a PR.

GitHub user jeking3 opened a pull request:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1101

THRIFT-3937: if the compiler is too old (gcc before 4.8) disable new compiler plugin during configuration

This will disable building the new compiler plug-in code if the compiler is too old (gcc earlier than 4.8).

You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:

$ git pull https://github.com/jeking3/thrift defect/THRIFT-3937

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1101.patch

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

This closes #1101

Github user jfarrell commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1101

License on this autoconf macro is GPLWithACException, we can not include it with Apache Thrift. see http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x

Github user jeking3 commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1101

I'll back out the autoconf changes then and we'll leave the CMake ones... we should probably document on the thrift web site that although gcc-4.2 or later is required, gcc-4.8 or later is required for compiler plug-in support.

jking3 we can not use the autoconf macro that you linked in your pull request due to a non-compatible license. GPLWithACException can not include it with Apache Thrift, this is outlined by Apache Legal at http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x.

Since we are deprecating autoconf, pre previous dev@ list discussions and votes, and this will be the last release with its support I would not invest too much time into a workaround for this. Perhaps a README update for the min required versions should be enough for this, thoughts?

jfarrell The apache web site says you need gcc-4.2 or later. We should either change that to gcc-4.8 or later (for 0.10.0) or state that gcc-4.8 or later is required for compiler plug-in support as of 0.10.0.

I resubmitted the pull request so that the cmake build properly disables plugin support if the compiler is gcc and the version is before 4.8.
Deprecating autoconf gets you a like...

+ MESSAGE_DEP(WITH_PLUGIN "Disabled due to older compiler")
+else()
+ MESSAGE_DEP(WITH_PLUGIN "Disabled by WITH_PLUGIN=OFF")
— End diff –

I mean, for example, `WITH_CPP` is a flag that users can directly set ON/OFF while `BUILD_CPP` is an internal flag that is based on `WITH_CPP` but can be disabled by `Boost-FOUND=OFF`.

The problem for `WITH_PLUGIN` is that, we're directly modifying this flag without internal equivalent, based on `BUILD_CPP` and `BUILD_COMPILER` values.
So we cannot tell what ON/OFF value the user has put to it.

About autotools flag, try `--enable-plugin=no` instead.
